The impermanence that is abandoned upon initial creation does not refer to the great elements mutually creating the great elements, because they are distinct from each other.

As for impermanence through transformation, it means that the substance of form transforms but the great elements do not transform. It is like gold being made into ornaments. The ornaments transform but the gold does not change. This is also like that.

Such various non-Buddhists falsely discriminate the nature of impermanence. They say that fire cannot burn the self-nature of fire, but only disperses it. If it could burn, then the created and the creator would all be annihilated.

Because they do not grasp external dharmas, because the three realms are only mind, because they do not speak of characteristics, because the various distinctions of the natures and locations of the great elements do not arise or cease, because they are neither the created nor the creator, because both the grasping and the grasped are all from discrimination, because they truly know the nature of the two graspings, because they understand that it is only the appearances of one's own mind, because they are free from the two views of existence and non-existence outside, because being free from the views of existence and non-existence, they do not discriminate the created and the creator.

The dharmas of the mundane, supramundane, and the highest supramundane are only one's own mind, neither permanent nor impermanent, yet one is unable to understand and falls into the evil views of the two extremes of non-Buddhists.
